The problem seems to be with the ngIf been next to the input, if you remove the ngIf it works correctly , also if you move the ngIf either after the button or outside of the form it also works ## ğŸ”¬ Minimal Reproduction To reproduce: - Open the https://stackblitz.com/edit/angular-8-dom-change-cancels-event?file=src%2Fapp%2Fapp.component.html - Open the stackblitz console - Click on the text field and then click on the submit button, a submit message should be logged but it doesn't ## ğŸ”¥ Exception or Error No exception or error is displayed ## ğŸŒ Your Environment **Angular Version:**

Issues.Title: fix(animations): not waiting for child component leave animations to finish on destroy in ivy
Issues.Body:
Fixes the animations engine not waiting for `:leave` animations to finish when a child component host is destroyed with Ivy. The issue seems to come from the fact that when removing a host element we end up calling `removeNode` on the namespace twice which in turn calls `triggerLeaveAnimation`. The first time everything is correct and the animation triggers, but the second time we don't check whether the animation was started and we remove the element immediately. These changes add some code to check that the leave animation hasn't been started already.

Fixes #33597.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "fix(animations): not waiting for child component leave animations to finish on destroy in ivy" (#34680)

Issues.Title: refactor(ivy): move hostVars/hostAttrs from instruction to DirectiveDef
Issues.Body:
# refactor(ivy): move `hostVars`/`hostAttrs` from instruction to `DirectiveDef`
    
This change moves information from instructions to declarative position:
- `ÉµÉµallocHostVars(vars)` => `DirectiveDef.hostVars`
- `ÉµÉµelementHostAttrs(attrs)` => `DirectiveDef.hostAttrs`
    
When merging directives it is necessary to know about `hostVars` and `hostAttrs`. Before this change that information was stored in the `hostBindings` function. This was problematic, because in order to get to that information the `hostBindings` would have to be executed. In order for `hostBindings` to be executed the directives would have to be instantiated. This means that the directive instantiation would happen before we had knowledge about the `hostAttrs` and as a result the directive could observe in the constructor that not all of the `hostAttrs` have been applied. This further complicates the runtime as we have to apply `hostAttrs` in parts over many invocations.
    
`ÉµÉµallocHostVars` was unnecessarily complicated because it would have to update the `LView` (and Blueprint) while existing directives are already executing. By moving it out of `hostBindings` function we can access it statically and we can create correct `LView` (and Blueprint) in a single pass.
    
This change only changes how the instructions are generated, but does not change the runtime much. (We cheat by emulating the old behavior by calling `ÉµÉµallocHostVars` and `ÉµÉµelementHostAttrs`) Subsequent change will refactor the runtime to take advantage of the static information.

Issues.Title: Angular uses old URL params when calling router.navigate from a resolver
Issues.Body: # ğŸ Angular uses old URL params when calling router.navigate from a resolver ### Affected Package Router. Specifically, [this line](https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/18d89c9c891844440a919b835c0f198a2b7395a6/packages/router/src/router.ts#L983) ### Is this a regression? Probably not, the inconsitency is caused by urlUpdateStrategy, which is a recent thing. ### Description When you call router.navigate from a resolver (e.g. when a resolver determines that the user does not have required permissions and you want to redirect to an error page), the query parameters of the URL are not taken from the URL. Rather, they are taken from rawUrlTree. This can cause a problem because the parameters might have changed with urlUpdateStrategy set to 'eager'. ## ğŸ”¬ Minimal Reproduction Here's a stackblitz repro based on heroes app from the router tutorial: https://stackblitz.com/edit/angular-router-redirect The example is changed from [the original](https://angular.io/guide/router#wrap-up-and-final-app) in the following ways: - it keeps the user ID in a query param instead of the path param, - initially, it loads /superheroes?id=11, - for /superhero path, it adds a RedirectingResolver that, when id=12, redirects to /crisis-center, - it has urlUpdateStrategy: 'eager'. *To trigger the error, follow these steps*: 1. Open https://stackblitz.com/edit/angular-router-redirect 1. You should start on the list of heroes (url is /superheroes?id=11), with hero 11 selected. 1. Click "Narco" (hero 12) (its URL is /superhero?id=12) 1. See that you get redirected to /crisis-center?id=11. However, if you look at RedirectingResolver in heroes-routing.module.ts, you'll see that: - it checks for query parameter and determines it's equal to 12 - it redirects to /crisis-center with merged query params With urlUpdateStragegy: 'eager' in app-routing.module.ts, I would expect to land at /crisis-center?id=12. ## ğŸŒ Your Environment **Angular Version:** Angular 8.2.14 on StackBlitz. ## Fix proposal This issue could be fixed by changing [this line](https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/18d89c9c891844440a919b835c0f198a2b7395a6/packages/router/src/router.ts#L983): const mergedTree = this.urlHandlingStrategy.merge(urlTree, this.rawUrlTree); to: const mergedTree = this.urlHandlingStrategy.merge(urlTree, this.browserUrlTree); Then, the code behaves as expected: you get redirected to /crisis-center?id=12. As browserUrlTree is updated in coordination with urlUpdateStrategy, it will correctly merge the new id when constructing the URL to redirect to.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Angular uses old URL params when calling router.navigate from a resolver" (#34675)

Issues.Title: Add consistent release tags for Angular npm packages
Issues.Body:
# ğŸš€ feature request

### Description

Please add a consistent release tag to the angular packages published to npm. Some packages already use release tags (e.g. @angular/core has `v5-lts` and `v4-lts` but no `v6-lts`, `v7-lts`, `v8-lts`). 
Other packages such as `@angular-devkit/schematics` have `v6-lts` but none of the other tags.

### Describe the solution you'd like
For each package that belongs to the angular ecosystem, please add a consistent release tag. This could then be used to more easily reference a consistent version of Angular in custom projects, in particular if they are not using the CLI.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Add consistent release tags for Angular npm packages" (#34672)

Issues.Title: createAngularJSTestingModule() breaks tests when used multiple times across unrelated spec files
Issues.Body:
# ğŸ bug report

### Affected versions
This bug is present since the very beginning (March, 22th, 2019) when `createAngularJSTestingModule()` was first added to `@angular/upgrade/static/testing` (there have only been two commits in that file, `angular\packages\upgrade\static\testing\src\create_angularjs_testing_module.ts`).

This problem only occurs (I suppose) with Jasmine. When using Jest, I think the test runs are already isolated so the problem might not show up there.

### Description

Calling `createAngularJSTestingModule()` immediately calls (under the hood) `angular.module(...)`, thus it "globally" adds the required angularJSTestingModule to the "global storage" of all angularJS modules. This works fine so long as you always require the same `angularModules` (like in `createAngularJSTestingModule(angularModules)`). However, once you have multiple test suites (i.e. different and totally unrelated spec files), you'll start to require different angularModules from time to time.

Now, due to `createAngularJSTestingModule()` immediately calling `angular.module()`, all previous invocations get overriden. "In the end", only the last call "wins" with its required angularModules. All previous calls are in vane, making their respective test suites fail, because they don't have (or load) the required `angularModules`.

To understand why this happens, you need to recall that Jasmine will first execute ALL describe blocks for ALL test files that are part of the test run (I guess this is needed so that Jasmine can provide the "focused specs" feature). Thus, when you stick to the notation provided in the official docs, you're lost:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1225659/71955749-79461b00-31e9-11ea-8eeb-9aded7cbe27b.png)

A workaround for the problem is to not call `angular.mock.module()` directly, but provide a function to `beforeEach` instead (which will only be called later, just before the test is run):

```
beforeEach(() => angular.mock.module(createAngularJSTestingModule(angularModules))); // notice the "() =>" to the left
```

The simplest solution would be to update the docs accordingly. However, when you're using `angular.mock.module.sharedInjector()` you'll most likely have a `beforeAll` instead of an `beforeEach`. While the workaround looks the same (just replace the beforeEach with beforeAll), you can no longer use a `beforeAll` in combination with `inject()`. Those calls need to be replaced instead with a `beforeEach`. This is due to `beforeAll(inject(...))` creating the injector too early which makes TestBed feel uncomfortable (erroring).

Maybe there's yet another, better, solution? 

When looking at the source code:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1225659/71956179-c1b20880-31ea-11ea-9cc0-5f3123d83dde.png)

Maybe it's feasible to use an internal counter to create different modules each time?
Or maybe it's possible to not call `angular.module()` at all, and provide a simple "module function" instead, that will be unique to the test suite?

@petebacondarwin
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "createAngularJSTestingModule() breaks tests when used multiple times across unrelated spec files" (#34670)

# ğŸš€ Feature request


### Command (mark with an `x`)
<!-- Can you pin-point the command or commands that are relevant for this feature request? -->
<!-- âœï¸edit: -->
- [ ] new
- [ ] build
- [x] serve
- [ ] test
- [ ] e2e
- [ ] generate
- [ ] add
- [ ] update
- [ ] lint
- [ ] xi18n
- [ ] run
- [ ] config
- [ ] help
- [ ] version
- [ ] doc

### Description
`ng serve` creates script tags for main.js, etc. with the `type="module"` attribute.  This prevents browsers from sending cookies with requests for these files.  Certain environment require cookies to be sent with all requests.  In production environments, Angular CLI's `ng build` command offers an option `--crossOrigin use-credentials` which applies a `crossorigin="use-credentials"` attribute to the script tag, causing headers to be sent.  In a development environment, though, `ng serve` does not offer the same options, so Angular CLI projects cannot be previewed.

### Describe the solution you'd like
Please enable the same `--crossOrigin` functionality for `ng serve` as exists in `ng build`.

Issues.Title: build: update husky to version ^4.0.0
Issues.Body:
This PR contains the following updates:

| Package | Type | Update | Change |
|---|---|---|---|
| [husky](https://togithub.com/typicode/husky) | devDependencies | major | [`^1.3.1` -> `^4.0.0`](https://renovatebot.com/diffs/npm/husky/1.3.1/4.0.1) |

---

### Release Notes

<details>
<summary>typicode/husky</summary>

### [`v4.0.1`](https://togithub.com/typicode/husky/releases/v4.0.1)

[Compare Source](https://togithub.com/typicode/husky/compare/v4.0.0...v4.0.1)

-   Fix: make Yarn silent. When Husky was installed with Yarn 1.21.1, hooks output was too verbose ([#​626](https://togithub.com/typicode/husky/issues/626)).

### [`v4.0.0`](https://togithub.com/typicode/husky/releases/v4.0.0)

[Compare Source](https://togithub.com/typicode/husky/compare/v3.1.0...v4.0.0)

-   Support `Yarn v2` new Plug'n'Play feature (thanks to [@​arcanis](https://togithub.com/arcanis))
-   Improve path handling on Windows (in particular with `Cygwin` and `Cmdr`)
-   Remove `dependencies` and simplify code
-   **Breaking** requires `Node 10+`

**Thanks to all contributors and everyone who is supporting Husky on [Open Collective](https://opencollective.com/husky), [GitHub sponsors](https://togithub.com/sponsors/typicode) and [Patreon](https://www.patreon.com/typicode)!**

### [`v3.1.0`](https://togithub.com/typicode/husky/releases/v3.1.0)

[Compare Source](https://togithub.com/typicode/husky/compare/v3.0.9...v3.1.0)

-   Add `pre-merge-commit` hook ([#​605](https://togithub.com/typicode/husky/issues/605))

### [`v3.0.9`](https://togithub.com/typicode/husky/releases/v3.0.9)

[Compare Source](https://togithub.com/typicode/husky/compare/v3.0.8...v3.0.9)

-   Reduce dependencies: replace `is-ci` with `ci-info` [#​579](https://togithub.com/typicode/husky/issues/579)

### [`v3.0.8`](https://togithub.com/typicode/husky/releases/v3.0.8)

[Compare Source](https://togithub.com/typicode/husky/compare/v3.0.7...v3.0.8)

-   Fix: git worktree support [#​580](https://togithub.com/typicode/husky/issues/580) 
-   Debug: check `GIT_DIR` environment variable when hooks are run

### [`v3.0.7`](https://togithub.com/typicode/husky/releases/v3.0.7)

[Compare Source](https://togithub.com/typicode/husky/compare/v3.0.6...v3.0.7)

Debug: display husky version and created at

### [`v3.0.6`](https://togithub.com/typicode/husky/releases/v3.0.6)

[Compare Source](https://togithub.com/typicode/husky/compare/v3.0.5...v3.0.6)

Debug: improve messages

### [`v3.0.5`](https://togithub.com/typicode/husky/releases/v3.0.5)

[Compare Source](https://togithub.com/typicode/husky/compare/v3.0.4...v3.0.5)

Fix: prevent `postinstall` from failing on windows [#​573](https://togithub.com/typicode/husky/pull/573)

### [`v3.0.4`](https://togithub.com/typicode/husky/releases/v3.0.4)

[Compare Source](https://togithub.com/typicode/husky/compare/v3.0.3...v3.0.4)

Fix: skip install earlier when `HUSKY_SKIP_INSTALL=1` ([#​563](https://togithub.com/typicode/husky/issues/563))

### [`v3.0.3`](https://togithub.com/typicode/husky/releases/v3.0.3)

[Compare Source](https://togithub.com/typicode/husky/compare/v3.0.2...v3.0.3)

Fix: prevent old hooks (husky `< 1.0`) to be run if new ones are defined (husky `>= 1.0` ) [#​556](https://togithub.com/typicode/husky/issues/556)

### [`v3.0.2`](https://togithub.com/typicode/husky/releases/v3.0.2)

[Compare Source](https://togithub.com/typicode/husky/compare/v3.0.1...v3.0.2)

-   Fix: add shebang to run.js ([#​528](https://togithub.com/typicode/husky/issues/528))

### [`v3.0.1`](https://togithub.com/typicode/husky/releases/v3.0.1)

[Compare Source](https://togithub.com/typicode/husky/compare/v3.0.0...v3.0.1)

-   Improve error message if git command fails

### [`v3.0.0`](https://togithub.com/typicode/husky/blob/master/CHANGELOG.md#​300)

[Compare Source](https://togithub.com/typicode/husky/compare/df97af21254ca033a05346df3deb61c046b9ea12...v3.0.0)

-   Fix HUSKY_SKIP_INSTALL=1 not skipping install
-   **Breaking change** husky requires now Git `>= 2.13.2`. If you're already using husky `v2` and don't use an old version of Git, you can safely upgrade.

### [`v2.7.0`](https://togithub.com/typicode/husky/blob/master/CHANGELOG.md#​270)

[Compare Source](https://togithub.com/typicode/husky/compare/v2.6.0...df97af21254ca033a05346df3deb61c046b9ea12)

Due to issues with Git `< 2.13.2`, this version is a rollback and is the same as husky `v2.4.1`. Changes introduced in `v2.5.0` and `v2.6.0` will be published in `v3.0.0`.

### [`v2.6.0`](https://togithub.com/typicode/husky/blob/master/CHANGELOG.md#​260)

[Compare Source](https://togithub.com/typicode/husky/compare/v2.5.0...v2.6.0)

-   Optional `HUSKY_USE_YARN` setting to use Yarn to run Husky
-   Add more debug information
-   Show a warning for Node `<= 8.6.0`

**Deprecated**

### [`v2.5.0`](https://togithub.com/typicode/husky/blob/master/CHANGELOG.md#​250)

[Compare Source](https://togithub.com/typicode/husky/compare/v2.4.1...v2.5.0)

-   Use more accurate git hooks directory resolution
-   Add `CWD` in debug messages

**Deprecated**

### [`v2.4.1`](https://togithub.com/typicode/husky/blob/master/CHANGELOG.md#​241)

[Compare Source](https://togithub.com/typicode/husky/compare/v2.4.0...v2.4.1)

-   Fix husky crash on install/uninstall with very old Node versions

### [`v2.4.0`](https://togithub.com/typicode/husky/blob/master/CHANGELOG.md#​240)

[Compare Source](https://togithub.com/typicode/husky/compare/v2.3.0...v2.4.0)

-   Add `HUSKY_SKIP_HOOKS` to skip all hooks

### [`v2.3.0`](https://togithub.com/typicode/husky/blob/master/CHANGELOG.md#​230)

[Compare Source](https://togithub.com/typicode/husky/compare/v2.2.0...v2.3.0)

-   Make `HUSKY_DEBUG=1` effective like `HUSKY_DEBUG=true`
-   Refactor script to point to `run-node/run-node` rather than `.bin/run-node`

### [`v2.2.0`](https://togithub.com/typicode/husky/blob/master/CHANGELOG.md#​220)

[Compare Source](https://togithub.com/typicode/husky/compare/v2.1.0...v2.2.0)

-   Improve Git worktree support

### [`v2.1.0`](https://togithub.com/typicode/husky/blob/master/CHANGELOG.md#​210)

[Compare Source](https://togithub.com/typicode/husky/compare/v2.0.0...v2.1.0)

-   Improve shell script portability by using `.` rather than `source`

### [`v2.0.0`](https://togithub.com/typicode/husky/blob/master/CHANGELOG.md#​200)

[Compare Source](https://togithub.com/typicode/husky/compare/v1.3.1...v2.0.0)

-   Update dependencies
-   Update messages
-   **Breaking change** drop `Node 6` support

</details>

Issues.Title: D3-color compiles incorrectly with buildOptimizer
Issues.Body:
# ğŸ Bug report ### Command (mark with an `x`) - [ ] new - [x] build - [x] serve - [ ] test - [ ] e2e - [ ] generate - [ ] add - [ ] update - [ ] lint - [ ] xi18n - [ ] run - [ ] config - [ ] help - [ ] version - [ ] doc ### Is this a regression? Yes, the previous version in which this bug was not present was: .... ### Description A clear and concise description of the problem... D3-Color appears to miscompile when using the --aot=true flag or whenever using buildOptimizer. ## ğŸ”¬ Minimal Reproduction ( Someone from the thread on d3-color already made a reproducable example) clone this project https://github.com/goldieswx/d3color-angular Should you either serve it or build using the prod argument. ng serve --prod ng build --prod Then the resulting app should crash with the OP stack trace ## ğŸ”¥ Exception or Error 



ERROR TypeError: i.rgb is not a function

    at dr (continuous.js.pre-build-optimizer.js:30)
    at ks.p [as ramp] (continuous.js.pre-build-optimizer.js:85)

    at dt.each (each.js.pre-build-optimizer.js:5)

Issues.Title: Unable to build library with AngularCompilerPlugin, no declarations created in the output
Issues.Body:
# ğŸ Bug report ### Command (mark with an `x`) - [ ] new - [x] build - [ ] serve - [ ] test - [ ] e2e - [ ] generate - [ ] add - [ ] update - [ ] lint - [ ] xi18n - [ ] run - [ ] config - [ ] help - [ ] version - [ ] doc ### Is this a regression? Yes, the previous version in which this bug was not present was: .... I haven't tried it before ### Description A clear and concise description of the problem... Since this is still not working: https://github.com/angular/angular/issues/34027 I'm trying to build an Angular Library with our current Webpack setup. When using AngularCompilerPlugin with Webpack declaration files are not generated. So I'm unable to import the built library. From webpack.config ``` new AngularCompilerPlugin({ tsConfigPath: helpers.rootPath('tsconfig.build.json'), mainPath: helpers.rootPath('src/index.ts') }), ``` From tsconfig.build.json ``` { "extends": "../../tsconfig.json", "compilerOptions": { "strictNullChecks": true, "noImplicitReturns": true, "rootDir": "./src", "declaration": true, "declarationMap": true, "declarationDir": "./dist", "outDir": "./dist" }, "files": [ "./src/index.ts" ] } ``` From tsconfig.json ``` { "compilerOptions": { "rootDir": ".", "baseUrl": ".", "target": "es5", "module": "commonjs", "moduleResolution": "node", "esModuleInterop": true, "allowSyntheticDefaultImports": true, "emitDecoratorMetadata": true, "experimentalDecorators": true, "removeComments": false, "noUnusedLocals": true, "noUnusedParameters": true, "noEmitHelpers": true, "noEmitOnError": false, "importHelpers": true, "noImplicitAny": false, "strictNullChecks": false, "strictPropertyInitialization": false, "pretty": true, "sourceMap": true, "declaration": false, "preserveConstEnums": true, "downlevelIteration": true, "lib": [ "dom", "es2015", "es2017.object", "es2017.string" ], "typeRoots": [ "./typings/", "./node_modules/@types" ], "paths": { "@oas/web-lib-core": ["./packages/web-lib-core/dist"], "@oas/web-lib-common": ["./packages/web-lib-common/dist"], "@oas/web-lib-angular-js": ["./packages/web-lib-angular-js/dist"], "@oas/web-lib-angular": ["./packages/web-lib-angular/src"], "@oas/web-lib-angular-2": ["./packages/web-lib-angular-2/dist"], "@oas/internal-lib-e2e": ["./packages/internal-lib-e2e/dist"], "rxjs/*": ["./node_modules/rxjs/*"], "zone.js/*": ["./node_modules/zone.js/*"], "@angular/*": ["node_modules/@angular/*"] } }, "compileOnSave": false, "buildOnSave": false } ``` ## ğŸ”¬ Minimal Reproduction https://github.com/JonWallsten/monorepo-new (might contain sensitive data from our organisation, so please ask to be a collaborator) Follow the instructions in the monorepo root ReadMe and check dist folder for packages/web-lib-angular-2 ## Issues.Title: Feature request: remove umd warning in ng-packager and allow `.mjs` format
Issues.Body:
### Description

if we use angular to build angular electron app library:

```
WARNING: No name was provided for external module 'electron' in output.globals â€“ guessing 'electron'
WARNING: No name was provided for external module 'path' in output.globals â€“ guessing 'path__default'
WARNING: No name was provided for external module 'fs' in output.globals â€“ guessing 'fs__default'
WARNING: No name was provided for external module 'os' in output.globals â€“ guessing 'os__default'
```

These warning are useless, because electron app does not use amd or browser globals, only commonjs and esmodule. 

At the same time, we also hope to have mjs support. Maybe in the future, we will execute the js code of es module in node. 
But apf only supports `.js` esm code and commonjs code supported in umd bundle, not `.mjs`

### Describe the solution you'd like

* remove umd bundle warning for output.globals (users will not use umd bundle if we use angular cli, users will not use umd bundle browser globals in commonjs)
* (optional) build lib with `.mjs` for future nodejs esm usage

### Describe alternatives you've considered
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Feature request: remove umd warning in ng-packager and allow `.mjs` format" (#16581)

Issues.Title: NativeDatepicker with MAT_DATE_LOCALE and en-GB swaps day/month continuously
Issues.Body: #### Reproduction Use StackBlitz to reproduce your issue: https://stackblitz.com/edit/angular-a5a7jk?file=src%2Fapp%2Fdatepicker-overview-example.html Steps to reproduce: 1. Add `{ provide: MAT_DATE_LOCALE, useValue: 'en-GB' },` 2. Focus field and type: "01/12/1988" and blur field 3. Focus field and press: "backspace" and "8" and blur field The same thing happens with locales like "de-DE" #### Expected Behavior What behavior were you expecting to see? You should see "01/12/1988" as you blur the field. When you edit that field with the same value, it should stay as "01/12/1988" #### Actual Behavior What behavior did you actually see? "01/12/1988" becomes "12/01/1988" and editing it again changes it back and forth to "01/12/1988" #### Environment - Angular: 8.2.3 - CDK/Material: 8.2.3 - Browser(s): OSX Chrome - OS Locale: United Kingdom - navigator.language: "en" #### Temporary workaround Just set the locale to something like "en". Potentially related: https://github.com/angular/components/issues/7823 and https://github.com/angular/components/issues/7143 After a little bit of debugging I see that: new Date("12/01/1988") is regarded as 1st December (en-US) as opposed to 12th January (en-GB) and then it's formatted using en-GB (opposite)
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "NativeDatepicker with MAT_DATE_LOCALE and en-GB swaps day/month continuously" (#18132)

Issues.Title: [Testing]: Mat checkbox doesn't change its state on click
Issues.Body:
#### What are you trying to do?

Unit testing angular application which includes angular material components. Specifically, material components are not behaving the same way in karma-chrome browser as they do in actual chrome browser.

#### What troubleshooting steps have you tried?
Listed below in Reproduction section.

#### Reproduction

Steps to reproduce:
1. `npx @angular/cli new small-app`: Create new angular app and select default prompts
2. `cd small-app` 
3. `yarn ng add @angular/material` (say, yes to all prompts)
4. Edit `src/app/app.component.html`
```html
<mat-checkbox>Check me!</mat-checkbox>
```
5. Edit `src/app/app.module.ts` & `src/app/app.component.spec.ts`
```typescript
import { MatCheckboxModule } from '@angular/material/checkbox';

imports: [
  ...
  MatCheckboxModule
]
```
6. `yarn start`. Clicking on checkbox changes the state of checkbox.
![yarn_start](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/13006107/71945014-93eda500-3193-11ea-96e4-cf4d88443ea8.gif)

7. `yarn test`. Clicking on checkbox does nothing.
![yarn_test](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/13006107/71945094-cdbeab80-3193-11ea-97bd-d4260b3e7ad4.gif)

8. Edit `angular.json` and remove material theme from `test`
![remove_theme](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/13006107/71945211-36a62380-3194-11ea-9c5e-b51d89ccdb33.gif)

9. `yarn test` again. This time checkbox changes its state on click.
![yarn_test_no_theme](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/13006107/71945241-4cb3e400-3194-11ea-91f6-c3da33670ca8.gif)

The same behaviour can be reproduced in other input components like [**Select**](https://material.angular.io/components/select/overview). With Material Select component, no options appear on click in test mode.

What am I missing here? What can I do so I don't have to remove material **theme** to have consistent experience between karma launched chrome browser and normal chrome mode?

#### Environment

- Angular: 8
- CDK/Material: 8
- Browser(s): Chrome 79
- Operating System (e.g. Windows, macOS, Ubuntu):  Mac OS Catalina
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "[Testing]: Mat checkbox doesn't change its state on click" (#18129)

Issues.Title: feat(list): Add single select mode.
Issues.Body:
Adds support for single selection to mat-selection list, using multiple="false" or [multiple]="false".

Styling is updated to match single-select mat-select panels, including a persistent highlight and hiding the check boxes.

As a side effect, support for updating the underlying SelectionModel after bootstrap is included (This was always technically possible as the field was public and mutable, but it is handled more gracefully now).

Issues.Title: Helper classes
Issues.Body:
<!--------

The Angular team can't provide general troubleshooting help. However, the extended community of
users can provide more help: 

StackOverflow: https://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/angular-material2
Gitter: https://gitter.im/angular/material2
Google Groups: https://groups.google.com/forum/#!forum/angular-material2

Issues should capture only bug reports and feature requests. However, we understand that 
it is not always clear whether an issue is caused by a bug or incorrect usage of a feature/component.

Most support requests will be automatically closed. If the answer is quickly obvious, though, we 
might be able to provide a brief answer.

-------->


#### What are you trying to do?

Coming from `bootstrap` (ngb-bootstrap) background. I am trying to center align contents like center align spinner in a card.

#### What troubleshooting steps have you tried?

Couldn't find any predefined way (or class) to align the contents. In the bootstrap, it is possible by using `text-center|left|right` or `float-left|right|` etc classes.

After googling for the issue, the only solution received is to write own CSS for aligning content.

There should also be classes to define margin, padding, etc.

A question for the same has been posted on Stackoverflow: https://stackoverflow.com/q/59612489/3719167
  
#### Environment

- Angular: 8.2.6
- CDK/Material: 8.2.3
- Browser(s): Any
- Operating System: macOS
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Helper classes " (#18120)

Issues.Title: build: add tsickle as explicit dependency
Issues.Body:
Adds tsickle as explicit dependency. This is necessary because
we access it from `node_modules/tsickle` in a Bazel target that
wraps tsc with tsickle.

In the past we just relied on the transitive dependency of
`@angular/bazel` being hoisted, but the hoisting is not guaranteed
if the lock file changes (e.g. when running `yarn upgrade`). In general,
dependencies we explicitly access, should be added as explicit dependencies.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "build: add tsickle as explicit dependency" (#18116)

Issues.Title: refactor(material): remove deprecated month constants from core
Issues.Body:
In the past, we accidentally published the month constants in
`@angular/material/core`. These were never intended for public
consumption but were only needed for testing. In v7, we deprecated
the constants (with the assumption that consumers might have used constants). 

Now, we can remove the constants now. There is no replacement for these
variables. Instead, use the zero-based month index on your own.

BREAKING CHANGE: Deprecated month constants from `@angular/material/core` have been
removed. These have been accidentally published in the past while they
were only intended for internal consumption in tests.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "refactor(material): remove deprecated month constants from core" (#18111)

Issues.Title: docs: use relative URLs in documentation so that the material.angular.io site can be hosted behind a firewall
Issues.Body:
Related to https://github.com/angular/material.angular.io/issues/623, the docs all have routes to other components hard-coded to the https://material.angular.io domain, rather than relative to the hosted documentation.

Please update them to use relative routes.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "docs: use relative URLs in documentation so that the material.angular.io site can be hosted behind a firewall" (#18108)
